citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Western Ecological Research Center, Sequoia-Kings Canyon Field Station
citeinfo.title: Southwest U.S. Mechanically Treated Chaparral Photo Series: Fuels

descript.abstract: Accurate, complete fuels data are critical for making fuel management decisions and for predicting fire behavior and fire effects. A fuel photo series is a useful reference that allows natural resource managers to quickly quantify fuel and vegetation properties by comparing on site conditions to a series of photos showing a range of calculated fuel loads within a similar vegetative community. While there are photo series available for a wide range of ecosystem types nationwide, this type of information is lacking for natural and mechanically treated chaparral. The most likely reason for this information gap is the difficulty in collecting and photographing fuels in these dense fuel types.
descript.purpose: The fuels and vegetation data accompanying this photo series were collected for a Joint Fire Science Project looking at the effects and effectiveness of mechanical treatments in chaparral. This study, which quantified fuel composition and structure, provided a unique opportunity to capture photographs of a range of treatments across a variety of chaparral types on the four southern California national forests.
descript.supplinf: Fuel loading in treatments was determined using a destructive plot-based method where all fuels were collected within five 0.5 m2 plot frames, separated into individual fuel classes and then weighed in the field to the nearest gram. A sample from each fuel class was then bagged, weighed in the field, oven dried at the lab, and then re-weighed to obtain fuel moisture. Final fuel masses were corrected for fuel moisture and expressed as oven-dry weight in Mg/ha.

procstep.procdesc: Development of the data set by the agency / individuals identified in the 'Originator' element in the Identification Info section of the record.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: Total downed woody fuel (Mg/ha)-The combined total of downed and dead fuel from woody suffrutescents, subshrubs and shrubs. The total is a sum of the 1, 10, 100, and 1000-hour fuel classes.

Fuels are classified into four categories by which they respond to changes in moisture. This response time is referred to as time lag. The four categories are: • 1-hour fuels: up to 1/4 inch in diameter. • 10-hour fuels: 1/4 inch to 1 inch in diameter. • 100-hour fuels: 1 inch to 3 inches in diameter. • 1000-hour fuels: 3 inches to 8 inches in diameter.

Fuels are classified into four categories by which they respond to changes in moisture. This response time is referred to as time lag. The four categories are: • 1-hour fuels: up to 1/4 inch in diameter. • 10-hour fuels: 1/4 inch to 1 inch in diameter. • 100-hour fuels: 1 inch to 3 inches in diameter. • 1000-hour fuels: 3 inches to 8 inches in diameter.

Fuels are classified into four categories by which they respond to changes in moisture. This response time is referred to as time lag. The four categories are: • 1-hour fuels: up to 1/4 inch in diameter. • 10-hour fuels: 1/4 inch to 1 inch in diameter. • 100-hour fuels: 1 inch to 3 inches in diameter. • 1000-hour fuels: 3 inches to 8 inches in diameter.

Fuels are classified into four categories by which they respond to changes in moisture. This response time is referred to as time lag. The four categories are: • 1-hour fuels: up to 1/4 inch in diameter. • 10-hour fuels: 1/4 inch to 1 inch in diameter. • 100-hour fuels: 1 inch to 3 inches in diameter. • 1000-hour fuels: 3 inches to 8 inches in diameter.
Live woody fuel -The combined total of live woody fuel from suffrutescents, subshrubs and shrubs.
Live herbaceous fuel-The combined total of live fuel from herbaceous plants.
Dead herbaceous and litter fuels -The combined total of dead herbaceous fuels from herbaceous plants and ground litter from all plants that does not fit into a woody fuel class.
Total fuel load (Mg/ha)-The combined total of downed woody fuels, live woody fuels, live herbaceous fuels, and dead herbaceous and litter fuels in Mg/ha
Total fuel load -The combined total of downed woody fuels, live woody fuels, live herbaceous fuels, and dead herbaceous and litter fuels in tons/acre.
Treatment debris cover -The percent of cover of dead and downed woody fuels, created by the treatment, that are on the ground surface.
Treatment debris depth -The depth of dead and downed woody fuels, created by the treatment, that are on the ground surface.
Live woody height -The maximum height of the live woody plants in the treated stand.
Total plant cover-The percent of cover of all living plants in the treated stand.

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describes the tabular data associated with the data set.
